openingRemarks:
Solve the following simultaneous equations

NB: Substitution method is used.

questions.answer:
\[ \begin{align*} y&=8+x && (1) \\ y&=16-x && (2) \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(y\) from equation (1) into equation (2):

\[ \begin{align*} (8+x)&=16-x \\ 8+x&=16-x \\ x+x&=16-8 \\ 2x&=8\\ \dfrac{2 x}{2}&=\dfrac{8}{2} \\ x&=4 \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(x=4\) into equation (1):

\[ \begin{align*} y&=8+4 \\ &=12 \end{align*} \]

\[ \begin{align*} y&=11-x && (1) \\ 2x+y&=14 && (2) \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(y\) from equation (1) into equation (2):

\[ \begin{align*} 2x+(11-x)&=14 \\ 2x+11-x&=14 \\ 2x-x&=14-11 \\ x&=3\\ \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(x=3\) into equation (1):

\[ \begin{align*} y&=11-3 \\ &=8 \end{align*} \]

\[ \begin{align*} a&=3 b-37 && (1) \\ 2b+3 a&=43 && (2) \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(a\) from equation (1) into equation (2):

\[ \begin{align*} 2 b+3(3 b-37)&=43 \\ 2 b+9b-111&=43 \\ 11b&=43+111 \\ 11b&=154\\ \dfrac{11b}{11}&=\dfrac{154}{11} \\ b&=14 \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(b=14\) into equation (1):

\[ \begin{align*} a&=3(14)-37 \\ &=42-37 \\ &=5 \end{align*} \]

\[ \begin{align*} c-d&=2 && (1) \\ 2 d&=c+2 && (2) \end{align*} \]

Proceed to make \(c\) the subject in equation (1):

\[ \begin{align*} c&=2+d && (3) \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(c\) from equation (3) into equation (2):

\[ \begin{align*} 2 d&=(2+d)+2 \\ 2 d&=2+d+2 \\ 2 d-d&=2+2 \\ d&=4 \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(d=4\) into equation (3):

\[ \begin{align*} c&=2+4 \\ &=6 \end{align*} \]

\[ \begin{align*} e&=2 f-10 && (1) \\ 3 f+2 e&=36 && (2) \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(e\) from equation (1) into equation (2):

\[ \begin{align*} 3 f+2(2 f-10)&=36 \\ 3 f+4 f-20&=36 \\ 7 f&=36+20 \\ 7f&=56\\ \dfrac{7 f}{7}&=\dfrac{56}{7} \\ f&=8 \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(f=8\) into equation (1):

\[ \begin{align*} e&=2(8)-10 \\ &=16-10 \\ &=6 \end{align*} \]

\[ \begin{align*} g&=3 h-28 && (1) \\ h+2 g&=28 && (2) \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(g\) from equation (1) into equation (2):

\[ \begin{align*} h+2(3 h-28)&=28 \\ h+6 h-56&=28 \\ 7 h&=28+56 \\ 7h&=84\\ \dfrac{7 h}{7}&=\dfrac{84}{7} \\ h&=12 \\ \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(h=12\) into equation (1):

\[ \begin{align*} g&=3(12)-28 \\ &=36-28 \\ &=8 \end{align*} \]

\[ \begin{align*} 3 j&=k+8 && (1) \\ 5 k+2 j&=-6 && (2) \end{align*} \]

Proceed to make \(k\) the subject in equation (1):

\[ \begin{align*} 3 j-8&=k &&(3) \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(k\) from equation (3) into equation (2):

\[ \begin{align*} 5(3 j-8)+2 j&=-6 \\ 15 j-40+2 j&=-6 \\ 15 j+2 j&=-6+40 \\ 17j&=34\\ \frac{17 j}{17}&=\frac{34}{17} \\ j&=2 \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(j=2\) into equation (3):

\[ \begin{align*} k&=3(2)-8\\ &=6-8 \\ &=-2 \end{align*} \]

\[ \begin{align*} 3m&=2 n && (1) \\ 3n+2 m&=91 && (2) \end{align*} \]

Proceed to make \(m\) the subject in equation (1):

\[ \begin{align*} 3m&=2n\\ \dfrac{3 m}{3} &=\dfrac{2 n}{3} \\ m&=\dfrac{2 n}{3} && (3) \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(m\) from equation (3) into equation (2):

\[ \begin{align*} 3n+2\left(\dfrac{2 n}{3}\right)&=91 \\ 3n+\dfrac{4 n}{3}&=91 \\ 3\times \left(3n+\dfrac{4 n}{3}\right)&=3 \times 91 \\ 3\times 3 n+3 \times \dfrac{4 n}{3}&=3\times 91 \\ 9n+4 n&=273 \\ 13n&=273\\ \frac{13 n}{13}&=\frac{273}{13} \\ n&=21 \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(n=21\) into equation (3):

\[ \begin{align*} m&=\dfrac{2 (21)}{3} \\ &=\dfrac{42}{3} \\ &=14 \end{align*} \]

\[ \begin{align*} 5p&=-3 q && (1) \\ 2q+3 p&=5 && (2) \end{align*} \]

Proceed to make \(p\) the subject in equation (1):

\[ \begin{align*} 5p&=-3 q\\ \frac{5 p}{5}&=\frac{-3 q}{5} \\ p&=\dfrac{-3 q}{5} && (3) \\ \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(p\) from equation (3) into equation (2):

\[ \begin{align*} 2q+3\left(\dfrac{-3 q}{5}\right)&=5 \\ 2q+\dfrac{-9 q}{5}&=5 \\ 5\times \left(2 q+ \dfrac{-9 q}{5}\right)&=5 \times 5 \\ 5\times 2 q+5 \times \dfrac{-9 q}{5}&=5 \times 5 \\ 10q-9 q&=25 \\ q&=25 \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(q=25\) into equation (3):

\[ \begin{align*} p&=\dfrac{-3(25)}{5} \\ &=\dfrac{-75}{5} \\ &=-15 \\ \end{align*} \]

\[ \begin{align*} r&=3 s-78 && (1) \\ s+2 r&=68 && (2) \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(r\) from equation (1) into equation (2):

\[ \begin{align*} s+2(3s-78)&=68 \\ s+6s-156&=68 \\ 7s&=68+156 \\ 7s&=224\\ \dfrac{7s}{7}&=\dfrac{224}{7} \\ s&=32 \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(s=32\) into equation (1):

\[ \begin{align*} r&=3(32)-78 \\ &=96-78 \\ &=18 \end{align*} \]

\[ \begin{align*} 3u&=v-32 && (1) \\ 5v+2u&=-129 && (2) \end{align*} \]

Proceed to make \(u\) the subject in equation (1):

\[ \begin{align*} 3u&=v-32\\ \dfrac{3u}{3}&=\dfrac{v-32}{3} \\ u&=\dfrac{v-32}{3} && (3) \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(u\) from equation (3) into equation (2):

\[ \begin{align*} 5v+2\left(\dfrac{v-32}{3}\right)&=-129 \\ 3 \times \left( 5v+ 2\left(\dfrac{v-32}{3}\right)\right)&=3 \times -129 \\ 3 \times 5v+3 \times 2\left(\dfrac{v-32}{3}\right)&=3 \times -129 \\ 15v+2 (v-32)&=-387 \\ 15v+2 v-64&=-387 \\ 17v&=-387+64 \\ 17v&=-323\\ \dfrac{17 v}{17}&=\dfrac{-323}{17} \\ v&=-19 \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(v=-19\) into equation (3):

\[ \begin{align*} u&=\dfrac{-19-32}{3} \\ &=\dfrac{-51}{3} \\ &=-17 \end{align*} \]

\[ \begin{align*} 9w+7z-208&=0 &&(1) \\ 0&=5z+11w-208 && (2) \end{align*} \]

Proceed to make \(w\) the subject in equation (1):

\[ \begin{align*} 9w+7z-208&=0 \\ 9 w&=208-7z \\ \dfrac{9 w}{9}&=\dfrac{208-7 z}{9} \\ w&=\dfrac{208-7 z}{9} && (3) \\ \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(w\) from equation (3) into equation (2):

\[ \begin{align*} -5 z-11\left(\frac{208-7 z}{9}\right)&=-208 \\ 5 z-\frac{2288-77 z}{9}&=-208 \\ 9\times \left(-5 z- \dfrac{2288-77 z}{9}\right)&=9 \times -208 \\ 9\times-5 z-9 \times \dfrac{2288-77 z}{9}&=9 \times -208 \\ -45 z-(2288-77 z)&=-1872 \\ -45 z-2288+77 z&=-1872 \\ 32 z&=-1872+2288 \\ 32z&=416\\ \dfrac{32 z}{32}&=\dfrac{416}{32} \\ z&=13 \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(z=13\) into equation (3):

\[ \begin{align*} w&=\dfrac{208-7(13)}{9} \\ &=\dfrac{208-91}{9} \\ &=\dfrac{117}{9} \\ &=13 \end{align*} \]

\[ \begin{align*} 7a+\dfrac{b}{2}&=55 && (1) \\ 4a+\dfrac{b}{4}&=30 && (2) \end{align*} \]

Proceed to clear fractions.

equation (1) × 2, equation (2) × 4:

\[ \begin{align*} 2 \times 7 a+2 \times \dfrac{b}{2}&=2 \times 55 \\ 14a +b&=110 && (3) \end{align*} \] \[ \begin{align*} 4 \times 4 a+4 \times \dfrac{b}{4}&=4 \times 30 \\ 16a+b&=120 && (4) \end{align*} \]

Make \(b\) the subject in equation (3):

\[ \begin{align*} 14a +b&=110\\ b&=110-14a && (5) \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(b\) from equation (5) into equation (4):

\[ \begin{align*} 16a+(110-14a)&=120 \\ 16a+110-14a&=120 \\ 16a-14a&=120-110 \\ 2a&=10\\ \dfrac{2a}{2}&=\dfrac{10}{2} \\ a&=5 \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(a=5\) into equation (5):

\[ \begin{align*} b&=110-14(5) \\ &=110-70 \\ &=40 \end{align*} \]

\[ \begin{align*} \dfrac{c}{2}+\dfrac{d}{3}&=29 && (1) \\ \dfrac{c}{4}+\dfrac{d}{5}&=17 && (2) \end{align*} \]

Proceed to clear fractions.

equation (1) × 6, equation (2) × 20:

\[ \begin{align*} 6 \times \dfrac{c}{2}+6 \times \dfrac{d}{3}&=6 \times 29 \\ 3 c+2 d&=174 && (3) \end{align*} \] \[ \begin{align*} 20 \times \dfrac{c}{4}+20 \times \dfrac{d}{5}&=20 \times 17 \\ 5 c+4 d&=340 && (4) \end{align*} \]

Make \( c \) the subject in equation (3):

\[ \begin{align*} 3 c+2 d&=174 \\ 3c&=174-2d\\ \dfrac{3 c}{3}&=\dfrac{174-2 d}{3} \\ c&=\dfrac{174-2 d}{3} && (5) \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(c\) from equation (5) into equation (4):

\[ \begin{align*} 5\left(\dfrac{174-2 d}{3}\right)+4 d&=340 \\ 3 \times 5\left(\dfrac{174-2 d}{3}\right)+3 \times 4d&=3\times 340 \\ 5(174-2 d)+12 d&=1020 \\ 870-10 d+12 d&=1020 \\ 2 d&=1020-870 \\ 2d&=150\\ \dfrac{2 d}{2}&=\dfrac{150}{2} \\ d&=75\\ \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(d=75\) into equation (5):

\[ \begin{align*} c&=\dfrac{174-2 (75)}{3}\\ c&=\dfrac{174-150}{3}\\ c&=\dfrac{24}{3}\\ c&=8 \end{align*} \]

\[ \begin{align*} 2p^{2}-q+5p&=9 && (1) \\ 2p-3q&=-17 && (2) \end{align*} \]

Proceed to make \(q\) the subject in equation (2):

\[ \begin{align*} 2p-3q&=-17\\ -3q&=-17-2p\\ \frac{-3q}{-3}&=\frac{-17-2p}{-3} \\ q&=\frac{-17-2 p}{-3} \\ &=\frac{-1(17+2 p)}{-3} \\ q&=\frac{17+2 p}{3} && (3) \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(q\) from equation (3) into equation (1):

\[ \begin{align*} 2p^{2}-\left(\frac{17+2 p}{3}\right)+5p&=9\\ 3 \times 2 p^{2}- 3 \times \left(\frac{17+2 p}{3}\right)+3 \times 5p&=3 \times 9 \\ 6 p^{2}-(17+2 p)+15p&=27 \\ 6 p^{2}-17-2 p+15p&=27 \\ 6 p^{2}-17+13p-27&=0 \\ 6 p^{2}+13 p-44&=0 \end{align*} \]

Compared to general form of quadratic equation, ie \(ax^2+bx+c=0\), a = 6, b = 13 and c = -44

Looking for integer factors of (6 × -44) which add up to 13 ... and those factors are -11 and 24

Therefore replace 13p with -11p + 24p \[ \begin{align*} 6 p^{2}+13 p-44&=0\\ 6 p^{2}-11p + 24p-44&=0\\ (6 p^{2}-11p) + (24p-44)&=0\\ p(6p-11)+4(6p-11)&=0\\ (6p-11)(p+4)&=0\\ 6p-11=0 && \text{or} \quad p+4=0 \\ 6p=11 && p=-4 \\ p=\dfrac{11}{6} \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(p=-4\) into equation (3):

\[ \begin{align*} q&=\frac{17+2 (-4)}{3} \\ &=\frac{17-8}{3} \\ &=\frac{9}{3}\\ &=3 \end{align*} \]

Substitute \(p=\dfrac{11}{6}\) into equation (3):

\[ \begin{align*} q&=\frac{17+2 \left(\dfrac{11}{6}\right)}{3} \\ &=\frac{17+\dfrac{11}{3}}{3} \\ &=\dfrac{\quad \dfrac{62}{3} \quad}{3} \\ &=\dfrac{62}{9}\\ \end{align*} \]
